title: Ancient Greek Drama
description: Step back in time to explore the origins of theater in ancient Greece!

questions.question: Greek drama originated as part of festivals honoring which god?
questions.explanation: Greek drama grew out of choral performances at festivals for Dionysus, the god of wine and festivity. The City Dionysia in Athens was the most important dramatic festival.

questions.question: Which playwright is considered the 'Father of Tragedy'?
questions.explanation: Aeschylus (c. 525-456 BC) is considered the father of tragedy. He introduced the second actor to the stage, allowing dialogue between characters, and wrote the 'Oresteia,' the only surviving Greek trilogy.

questions.question: What role did the 'chorus' play in Greek drama?
options: They sang, danced, and commented on the action
They sold refreshments to the audience
questions.explanation: The chorus was a group of performers who sang, danced, and spoke in unison. They provided background information, commented on the action, and represented ordinary citizens reacting to events.

questions.question: In Sophocles' 'Oedipus Rex,' what terrible truth does Oedipus discover about himself?
options: He has unknowingly killed his father and married his mother
He has been blind since birth
He is not the true king
questions.explanation: Oedipus, investigating a plague on Thebes, discovers he has fulfilled the prophecy he tried to escape: he killed his father Laius and married his mother Jocasta. Aristotle considered it the perfect tragedy.

questions.question: Aristophanes was the greatest writer of which type of Greek drama?
questions.explanation: Aristophanes (c. 446-386 BC) is the greatest surviving writer of Old Comedy. His plays like 'Lysistrata,' 'The Birds,' and 'The Frogs' used humor and satire to comment on Athenian politics and culture.

questions.question: What were the large, open-air theaters where Greek dramas were performed called?
questions.explanation: Greek amphitheaters were built into hillsides with remarkable acoustics. The Theatre of Dionysus in Athens, which could seat up to 17,000 spectators, was the most important performance venue.

questions.question: What is the Greek concept of 'catharsis' in drama, as described by Aristotle?
options: The final scene of a play
The emotional cleansing the audience experiences through pity and fear
A religious ritual before the performance
questions.explanation: In his 'Poetics,' Aristotle described catharsis as the purging of emotions — pity and fear — that the audience experiences through watching tragedy. This remains a foundational concept in dramatic theory.

questions.question: Why did Greek actors wear masks?
options: To protect against sun and weather
To amplify their voices and show emotions visible to distant spectators
To hide their identities from the audience
questions.explanation: The large masks had exaggerated expressions visible from far away in the vast amphitheaters and included a built-in megaphone effect. Actors could also play multiple roles simply by changing masks.

questions.question: Euripides' 'Medea' tells the story of a woman who takes revenge on her husband for what reason?
options: He abandoned her for a younger princess
questions.explanation: In 'Medea' (431 BC), the sorceress Medea is abandoned by her husband Jason (of Argonaut fame) when he plans to marry the princess of Corinth. Her terrible revenge shocked ancient audiences.

questions.question: What was the 'deus ex machina' in Greek theater?
options: A god lowered by crane to resolve the plot
questions.explanation: 'Deus ex machina' (god from the machine) referred to a god character lowered onto stage by a crane to resolve an impossible situation. Euripides was known for using this device. The term now means any contrived plot resolution.

questions.question: The three great Greek tragedians were Aeschylus, Sophocles, and who?
questions.explanation: Euripides (c. 480-406 BC) was the third great tragedian. He was known for his psychological realism and sympathetic portrayals of women and outcasts. Of his roughly 90 plays, 18 survive.

questions.question: The word 'thespian,' meaning actor, derives from which figure in Greek theater history?
questions.explanation: Thespis is credited as the first person to step out of the chorus and speak as an individual character, around 534 BC. This made him the first known 'actor,' and performers are still called 'thespians' in his honor.

questions.question: In Greek tragedy, what is 'hubris'?
options: A dance performed by the chorus
Excessive pride that leads to a hero's downfall
questions.explanation: Hubris — excessive pride or arrogance that defies the gods — is the most common tragic flaw (hamartia) in Greek tragedy. It leads characters like Oedipus and Creon to their destruction.

questions.question: Aeschylus's 'Oresteia' trilogy deals with what family's tragic history?
questions.explanation: The 'Oresteia' (458 BC) follows the cursed House of Atreus through Agamemnon's murder by his wife Clytemnestra, their son Orestes' revenge, and his trial before Athena's court in Athens.

questions.question: What prize did playwrights compete for at the City Dionysia festival?
questions.explanation: Winning playwrights at the City Dionysia received a crown of ivy (sacred to Dionysus) and great public honor. Three tragedians each presented a trilogy of tragedies plus a satyr play, competing for first, second, and third place.
